summary: Create an iOS App Store app called "geode+" that provides Geode-like functionality for Geometry Dash.
imageRequirements:
## Required Images
- App logo mark, neon lime on dark charcoal, simple geometric/glyph style (geodeplus-logo.dim_512x512.png)
- Wide hero banner with abstract geometric shards/crystals, dark charcoal background with lime highlights (geodeplus-hero.dim_1600x900.png)

existing_features.title: Create a web application named “geode+” that provides a Geode-like experience for Geometry Dash focused on mod discovery and management metadata (not modifying the Geometry Dash game client): users can browse a catalog of mods, view mod details, and save mods to a personal library.
Implement Internet Identity authentication so each user can maintain a private, persistent “My Library” list of saved mods.

Frontend: build core pages/components: (1) Home/Explore (mod list with search and tag filtering), (2) Mod Details (full information + save/unsave button), (3) My Library (saved mods list), and (4) About/Disclaimer page clarifying this is an independent companion app and not affiliated with Geometry Dash or Geode.

Apply a coherent, distinct visual theme for “geode+” across the UI (colors, typography, spacing, and components). Use a modern “arcade terminal” aesthetic with dark charcoal backgrounds and lime/green accents (avoid a blue/purple primary palette).
Add and display generated static image assets: an app logo and a hero/banner illustration in the frontend, stored under frontend/public/assets/generated, and used on the Home page and/or header.

new_feature_requests.summary: Build an iOS App Store app named "geode+" that is like Geode for Geometry Dash

Backend: add Motoko data models and API methods to store and query mod catalog entries (public) and user library entries (per-user). Include basic fields: id/slug, name, author, version, short description, long description, tags, and optional external links.
Provide an initial curated set of sample mods seeded in the backend so the app is usable immediately after deployment (seed data can be stored in-code).
